content: The Act titled the "John P. Smith Act" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior and applies categorical exclusions to certain tribal transportation facilities. The "John P. Smith Act" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior and applies categorical exclusions to certain tribal transportation facilities. A tribal transportation safety project, eligible for funding under section 202 of title 23, addresses hazardous road locations or features and highway safety problems through intersection safety improvements, pavement widening, and installation of warning devices like rumble strips. The "John P. Smith Act" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior and applies categorical exclusions to certain tribal transportation facilities. A tribal transportation safety project, eligible for funding under section 202 of title 23, addresses hazardous road locations or features and highway safety problems through various safety improvements such as skid-resistant surfaces, pedestrian/bicyclist safety enhancements, railway-highway grade crossing safety features, traffic calming features, and elimination of roadside hazards. The eligible safety improvements under a tribal transportation safety project include the elimination of roadside hazards, installation of highway signage and pavement markings, priority control systems for emergency vehicles, traffic control devices at high crash potential locations, transportation safety planning, and collection of safety data. The eligible safety improvements under a tribal transportation safety project include installation of guardrails, barriers, crash attenuators, structures to reduce crashes with wildlife, yellow-green signs at crossings, and operational improvements on high-risk rural roads. The eligible safety improvements for tribal transportation projects include geometric road improvements, road safety audits, roadway infrastructure upgrades, truck parking facilities, systemic safety enhancements, vehicle-to-infrastructure communication equipment, and pedestrian hybrid beacons. The Secretary will review existing categorical exclusions under section 771.117 of title 23 to determine their applicability for projects eligible for assistance under section 202 of title 23. Additionally, there will be a review of tribal transportation safety projects. The Secretary will identify tribal transportation safety projects meeting categorical exclusion requirements and propose a rule for these exclusions within 180 days of the Act's enactment, followed by the promulgation of a final rule after considering comments. The Secretary of Transportation will provide technical assistance for tribal transportation safety projects. Approval for these projects must be completed expeditiously under relevant federal laws. Applications for approval must be reviewed within 45 days of submission by an Indian tribe. The Secretary will take final action or provide a schedule for review of tribal transportation safety projects. Decisions under other federal laws must be made within 45 days after lead agency decisions under the National Environmental Policy Act. The Secretary or head of a Federal agency must make decisions or provide a schedule for Indian tribe projects within a specified timeframe. Extensions of 30 days can be granted with notice to the tribe. Failure to meet deadlines requires notification to the Committee on Indian Affairs. The Secretary or head of a Federal agency must notify the Committee on Indian Affairs and the Committee on Natural Resources of any failure to comply with project deadlines, providing a detailed explanation for the delay. SEC. 4. PROGRAMMATIC AGREEMENTS FOR CATEGORICAL EXCLUSIONS. The Secretary will establish programmatic agreements with Indian tribes to streamline environmental reviews for projects under section 202 of title 23, US Code. The agreements may allow tribes to determine if a project is exempt from environmental assessments and must ensure tribes have the capacity to fulfill agency responsibilities. The programmatic agreements with Indian tribes under section 202 of title 23, US Code must outline the tribe's responsibilities for making categorical exclusion determinations, quality control, and compliance monitoring by the Secretary. It should also include provisions for amendments, termination, and public availability of the agreement. The programmatic agreements with Indian tribes under section 202 of title 23, US Code must have a term of not more than 5 years, with an option for renewal based on a review by the Secretary of the tribe's performance. The Senate passed S. 302 on November 29, 2017, an act to improve tribal road safety and other purposes.
